name: Dioscorea villosa
Relationship: Antidotes: CHAMOM.; CAMPH. Compare: COLOC. (differs in modalities); NUX; CHAM.; BRY.
Modalities: Worse: evening and night; lying down
Better: motion in open air; pressure

Heart: Angina pectoris; pain back of sternum into arms; labored breathing; feeble action of heart
Especially with flatulence and pain through chest and tightness across
Head: Dull pain in both temples; better pressure, but worse afterwards
Buzzing in head
Respiratory: Chest does not seem to expand on breathing
Stomach: Pain along sternum and extending into arms
Eructations of sour, bitter wind, with hiccough
Sharp pain in epigastrium, relieved by standing erect
Belching of large quantities of offensive gas
Sinking at the pit of the stomach; pyrosis
Mouth dry and bitter in morning, tongue coated, no thirst
Rectum: Diarrhoea , yellowish, followed by exhaustion, as if flatus and feces were hot
Hemorrhoids, with darting pains to liver; look like bunches of grapes or red cherries; protrude after stool, with pain in anus
Mind: Calls things by the wrong name
Abdomen: Sharp pains from liver, shooting upward to right nipple
Renal colic, with pain in extremities
Griping, cutting in hypogastric region, with intermittent cutting in stomach and small intestines
Colic; better walking about; pains radiate from abdomen to back, chest, arms; worse, bending forwards and while lying
Rumbling, with emission of much flatus
Pains suddenly shift to different parts; appear in remote localities, as fingers and toes
Pain from gall-bladder to chest, back, and arms
Female: Uterine colic; pains radiate from uterus
Extremities: Sciatica; pains shoot down thigh; worse, right side; better, when perfectly still
Cramps in flexors of fingers and toes
Felons in beginning, when pricking is first felt
Male: Pains shoot into testicles from region of kidneys
Emissions in sleep, or from sexual atony, with weak knees
Strong-smelling sweat on scrotum and pubes

details: As a remedy for many kinds of PAIN, especially colic, and in severe, painful affections of abdominal and pelvic viscera; it ranks with the polychrests of the Materia Medica. Persons of feeble digestive powers; tea-drinkers, with much flatulence. GALL STONE COLIC.
